comments.commentBody:
Trump’s biggest problem in the Red States is that his national campaign is exactly the same as his primary campaign. Trump hasn’t evolved his campaign to cater to the total American Electorate. Trump's current national campaign is preaching to the choir. Those GOP primary voters are already with him. Trump has made no effort to expand his support. Unfortunately for Trump, he learned the wrong lessons from the primaries for running his national campaign.

Perhaps Trump really believes his own lies that "everybody" loves him.

Donald Trump scares me, infuriates me - and makes me really seethe with anger - but that's how he works because he knows which buttons to push.  Whatever you feel about him, he makes sure that you can't ignore him - and, by golly, he know how to suck up every emotion you have - especially the rage and negativity  that we usually manage to keep under wraps.

replies.commentBody:
Your analysis is extremely faulty.

A 20% drop in people staying at a Trump hotel has absolutely no correlation towards making the conclusion that only 20% of the American Voters choose Clinton while 80% choose Trump.

In 2012, over 126 Million people voted in that US Presidential election. Based on that number, I could safely state that at least 95% of the American Voters have never stayed nor will every stay in a Trump Hotel. Therefore, Trump Hotel bookings have absolutely no correlation as to how the American election will turn out.

Besides, in modern history, the highest winning margin by a US Presidential candidate was 61.9% for Lyndon Johnson over 38.5% for Barry Goldwater in 1964.

WEB: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1964

I can unconditionally predict that there is no way Trump could win with 80% of the vote and Clinton lose with only 20% of the vote in the upcoming 2016 US Presidential Election.

Tu lógica explica Perón, Menem y los K.
Felicitaciones.

The remainder 80%, continue as usual and
most probably , they vote Mr Trump, since they expend money in Mr Trump facility.

This DIY poll are more realistic, fair and accurate, than the media poll.
Sorry about my poor English .
From Argentine God bless America!

Keep the populace dumb and in fear of the "others" has been the Republican philosophy for decades by dismantling and defunding a public education system and elevating NRA/ White Nationalist propaganda. Apparently, we are now seeing the results of their dirty work not only in the behavior of their supporters but also those on the top. Disturbing!

A successful" mobilization" strategy requires a paid-for, in place professionally staffed organizational effort.

You cannot expect paid TV advertising (if they ever start running it); rallies; or even email alerts from the NRA to get many of those uneducated, ESPN watching with a six-pack white men to go to the polls. That takes a ground game that should have begun moths ago and didn’t.

The Trump campaign has "nada" because they are, effectively, broke ($93 million raised won’t keep a national campaign organization afloat for more than a couple of months) and have little $$$ to devote to either paid advertising or a GOTV effort; the latter which is being left to GOP state party organizations to provide using their own, in-state raised resources. Good luck with that.

Even at this late date, if Trump amazed us by actually spending his own money to put a GOTV and TV/Radio advertising campaign in place, it would still be too late to be effective.

This dog won't hunt.
I really wonder what Trump has to do to get these people to dump him.  The only person who should vote for him is Putin.

replies.commentBody:
As always, it depends on what degree you get. I have a Master's in mathematics and am in my mid thirties and I have never had difficulty landing a job, while my sister's degree in communications has done nothing for her.

Where my generation was really let down was at home with our parents telling us we could be anything we wanted to be. Basic logic dictates that only so many people can become english or history professors. The one area of surprise is with lawyers. I didn't see that crash coming.

comments.commentBody: It’s only younger college-educated individuals (such as those who preferred Sanders) who are beginning to come across some of what non-college-educated people of all ages are. The price of college today combined with job prospects make a college degree of less value than it was not that very long ago. It’s a somewhat similar phenomenon, although worse, because education (with the complete dependence on institutions of higher learning for credentialing that this implies) is supposed to be the path to economic mobility.

you exaggerate.

it's been scientifically proven that cockroaches and keith Richards would survive.....

comments.commentBody: Why isn't the press covering the real story? A trump presidency surely means death for us all, and the extinction of every living thing on the face of the earth.
Could we get s story about voter registration and ground game?  Any evidence of increased voter registration among working-class white men, for example?

In this state if you are white you are a republican - if black you are a democrat. Trump has changed all that - his denunciations of veterans and comments about women has turned off even a lot of people with no education.

Hopefully his loss in November will be reflected in house and senate races - how wonderful it would be to see democrats controlling all three segments of government.

This is great analysis but it a 3rd key variable could be added: women!

Trump is exposed to losing many Romney-voting women including those without a university education.

Trump's not-so-subtle insinuation yesterday to commit violence against a fellow woman is another offense that will push working class women away.

replies.commentBody: Trump is disgusting and an embarrassment to humanity.
Bill Maher joked that while Ivanka loves her father, she kind of wishes he would sleep in a different bed...

I have 2 kids in middle school, and Trump is apparently the biggest joke on the school bus.  The kids know he's damaged goods and his followers are obeying their inner meanie.  So there's hope for the future of this country.

comments.commentBody:
I find children to be the best judge of character. They haven’t been polluted by society YET! Look at differences between how children and babies interact with President Obama or Hillary Clinton vs Donald Trump. Children have no problem showing how they feel.

Trump on his own child;

Trump on “The View” “I don’t think Ivanka would do that [pose for nude photographs] inside the magazine,” Trump says, speaking for his daughter. “Although she does have a very nice figure. I’ve said that if Ivanka weren’t my daughter, perhaps, I would be dating her.”

And then, as the words he had just spoken formed meaning in his mind, Trump asked: “Is that terrible?”

Joy Behar asks “Who are you, Woody Allen?” Everyone laughs, including Donald Trump, who remarks “That’s very good.”

“He told Rolling Stone that if he weren’t happily married and his daughter’s father, he’d — well, he didn’t finish the thought, but you can guess what he meant."

replies.commentBody:
I was one of those people. I left the Republican party after G.W.'s first term.

It's often more than just doing what has always been done. For a lot of people political rhetoric is woven into all of the other things we're taught by our families and pulling away from that can be tough to do.

Growing up, you trust your parents to teach you about the world and it's no fun waking up to the fact that they might have been wrong about some things.

We need to have some empathy and compassion for these people.

Before my mother died a few years ago, she said that she could no longer support the Republican party and that it bore no relationship to what it was when she first started voting.

comments.commentBody:
There are people voting republican because their daddy or grandfather did. It is like the scene out of Forest Gump where Lt. Dan says “there has been a member of my family that has died in every American war” but with the republican voters it would be “members of my family have voted republican in every American presidential season”. Interestingly enough, the results of both Lt. Dan’s family and the family members who vote republican, both pretty much end with the same results. The cult of “family” passing down through the years the dysfunction all held up proudly as if it was an honor to do so. Women and children being forced to vote republican because their dominating husband or father forced them to do so. Male driven religions, Adams rib, reducing women and children to be less than whatever man has been assigned to govern them. Meanwhile what the GOP stands for is against the very needs of those women and children and in doing so is actually against any healthy man’s family.

Liberals speak for the weak and oppressed; want change and justice, even at risk of chaos.

Conservatives speak for institutions and traditions; want order even at the cost to those at the bottom.

[Psychologist Jonathan Haidt studies the five moral values that form the basis of our political choices, whether we're left, right, or center]

For so many in our country, the only chance of 'making it' relies on the helping effects of a broad safety net. But as we've witnessed over the years, the Republican Party seems to do their darnedest to keep widening the openings in our national safety net, thus making it easier and easier for the neediest to slip through. Marginalized, this segment of our society stagnates, and because they're deprived that 'leg-up', that opportunity to righten their ship to compete with others on a level playing field, they resign themselves to being second best, they give up,   they fail. And mind you, this is NOT who Trump is attracting. Trump Supporters are the angry white, lower, uneducated working class who view those dangling from that 'social safety net' as the takers, those lazy, shiftless 'welfare types' stuffed into city and rural isolation, particularly minorities. And the Trump Supporters intend to help keep these marginalized groups, their struggling competitors, right there by voting Republican, and this time around, it just happens to be Donald Trump.

Trumps biggest problem is that there is a group who will not vote for him, which overlaps with many of the other groups that ordinarily would vote Republican: The People-who--refuse-to-vote-for-a-bigoted-narcissistic-dishonest-idiot-vote.

replies.commentBody: Hang in there.

Furgle, correct me if I'm wrong, but at the risk of nit-picking, I was under the impression that West Virginians actually tend to approve of Obamacare. It's my understanding that, as one of the few red states (along with Kentucky and Arkansas) which retained a Democratic governor for at least most of the Obama presidency, WV did implement enough of Obamacare's features to experience a significant drop in its uninsured rate.

Their Trump strategy is going to backfire.  If he wins, I get a tax cut, they get nothing.  And if he loses, they wear a stigma as people who supported a creepy, bigoted hatemonger for president.  And still they get nothing, and it will be easier for me not to care.

comments.commentBody:
I live in WV and know PLENTY of good ol' boys who are planning to vote for Trump. Quite a few women, too. Any suggestion on my part that Trump might not be a perfect savior is met with contempt and disgust, if not downright hatred. Not that it stops me from running my mouth, but it does make me careful not to take it too far.
Trump might be in danger of losing a few red states, but the only way he could lose here is by visiting each home in the state, personally kicking the homeowner in the rear end, all while talking about how great immigrants and Obamacare are. And - even then - I think it would be close.

It appears the Republican Party is destined to become the party of the non-college educated. And the establishment seems to be surprised by this development. Apparently they're not able to hear the dog-whistles they're blowing on.

I found this one of Mr. Cohn's more informative pieces, especially the part about how Trump is "tapped out" when it comes to white voters in red states. I'm a bit concerned with how quickly he dismissed the notion of mobilization though. Do you have estimates of the turnout rates for these groups in 2012? How big is the group of white, non-college-educated previous nonvoters in these states?

In my analyses of recent polling data I've seen Clinton doing better in surveys limited to likely voters. That makes sense methodologically since many likely-voter screens use reported prior voting as a predictor. I see Trump as appealing to a more discouraged group in the citizenry who have been turned off from politics but possibility awaiting a "leader." I'm curious if you also have estimates of the size of that group, probably non-college whites who did not vote in 2008 or 2012. I'm willing to believe as you suggest that there are not enough of them to matter, but I'd like know how many there are.

Of perhaps even more interest is the number of nonvoting Hispanics in the states. Census Bureau data shows there were about 10 million Hispanic citizens who were not registered to vote in 2012. Mobilizing them may be more important for Clinton than mobilizing non-college whites is for Trump.

http://www2.census.gov/programs-surveys/cps/tables/p20/568/table04b.xls

replies.commentBody: Disliking Clinton is easy. Disliking her enough to place a kamikaze vote for Trump is hard to imagine. There is such a thing as self-interest when casting a ballot, which explains why people of the caliber that requires warning labels on soup cans are voting Trump. His campaign should be handing out T-shirts that state "I'm with Stupid" and an arrow pointing up.

comments.commentBody:
I think this analysis underestimates the strong dislike for Hillary Clinton among college educated white men. A further drill down into this specific demographic will likely reveal that many who voted for Romney will vote for Trump but for a different reason. Many white men, regardless of education level, who identifiy as being part of the working class or sees their jobs and livelihoods threatened are ripe to support Trump.

More importantly, many Educated white men are likely less willing to publicly admit their support of Trump because they are smart enough to recognize it potentially opens the door to criticism for publicly embracing someone whose actions and words are largely undefendable to most decent people. I suspect that when they walk into the voting booth with no one watching, many will vote for Trump.

replies.commentBody:
Your first point is a bit of a misconception. I expect Black turnout to be similar to the last two elections. While Obama is not on the ballot Trump is. Any fall off from Obama will be more then made up by the fear of Trump. Running a bigot will have a great effect on the turnout of minorities.

Besides black turnout wasn't particularly low before Obama and it was greater at his reelection then election. It's very possible this is the new normal.

"Running a bigot will have a great effect on the turnout of minorities."

Curiously, David Duke has a higher % of the Black vote (in LA) than Trump does nationally.

comments.commentBody:
Two points need to be added. First, Obama had really abnormal turnover among blacks. It is very unlikely to be repeated in total numbers. Ditto the young, especially young women who were so negative to Clinton in the primary. Both make Georgia hard to win.

Second, states tend to move in tandem. In 2012, Obama won Florida by 1, Ohio by 3, Virginia by 4, Colorado by 5, Pennsylvania by 5, Iowa by 6. Trump should be doing best in Florida and Ohio as he is. If Virginia and Colorado are out of reach, that is a real problem.

Romney won North Carolina by 2, Georgia by 8, Arizona by 9, Missouri by 9, and Indiana. If he is going to lose by any substantial margin, it is natural that Georgia and Arizona would be the first after NC to go.

replies.commentBody: Trump is already trying to weasel out of the debates.  He knows HRC will make him look like the fool he is.

Mr. Kotwal: Pretty off the mark comment. Nate Cohn is giving a view of where things stand today based on rigorous statistical analysis. Using science to analyze things makes him a hired hack for Hillary?

comments.commentBody: The election is going to be held in November when the real election will be held. Trump has received a ferocious pounding by the press, media, pundits as well as by Bush and Romney and establishment Republicans and just as I take what Trumps says with a grain of salt, I take Nate Cohn's comments with even a tinnier grain of salt. The debates have not taken place and the unraveling of the Clinton's extreme carelessness is just beginning and we have to remain open to the September and October surprises. So as they say around here. Hold your horses and wait for the run for the roses, the real elections when real people vote not the hired hacks of Hillary.

comments.commentBody: This also explains why the Republican Party puts so much effort into defunding education and turning it over to corporate manipulation.

replies.commentBody: Reread the labels on the infographics -- It's not claiming that 60% of people don't have college degrees but rather that of the white voters without college degrees 60% of them voted Republican in 2012.

How come people with a college education have not taken a look at such basic information about the U.S.? It seems colleges are pretty good at selling a sense of entitled smartness without actually providing the basics.

Most people shouldn't have a college degree. College (a legitimate one) is extremely rigorous and challenging, and most people simply do not have the mental capacity to make it through. And that's okay.

What is not okay are fake colleges like Phoenix who con financially illiterate young people who can barely read into taking out huge loans that cannot be discharged and throw them into dumbed down, useless classes for a diploma that is essentially worthless.

comments.commentBody: Wow, a lot of people don't have college degrees in this country. Sadly, that explains a lot. Most of the states are in the fifty percent or higher range and that concerns me.
